*Today’s Verse:*

*Zacchaeus stood and said to the Lord; behold Lord,*

*half of my goods I give to the poor; and if I have*

*taken any thing from any man by false accusation,*

*I will restore to him fourfold. *(Lk 19:10)

(read Lk. 19:1-10)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Everyone knew that tax collectors were becoming rich

by gouging their fellow Jews. No wonder the people

muttered when Jesus went home with Zacchaeus, the

tax collector. But despite the fact that Zacchaeus was

both a cheater and a turn coat, Jesus loved him, and

in response the tax collector was converted. In every

society, certain groups of people are considered

“untouchable” because of their political views, their

immoral behavior, or their life style.

*Jesus loves them and they need to hear the Good *

*News.*

Remember the words we pray, “forgive us our trespasses *as we* forgive
those who trespass against us.



Remember too Mt. 7:1 “Judge not that you be not judged.”

*Pastor Al*

subject   : Subject: SEEKING WISE COUNSEL (1-2-2020)
from      : Pastor Sather <pastor.sather5@gmail.com>

date      : Wed, 1 Jan 2020 19:01:39 -0600

*Today’s Verse:*

*Trust in the Lord with all your heart and lean not on your own
understanding; in all your ways submit to *

*Him, and He will make your paths straight. *(Pro. 3:5-6)



*Today’s Reflections:*

When we have an important decision to make, we sometimes think we can not
even trust God. In my experience it is because I have not had the patience
to wait on God. (Shame on me!) At those times I have forgotten that God
knows what is best for me. I have found through the years that He is a
better judge of

what I need. At the same time we should not omit

careful thinking or belittle our God-given ability to reason; but we should
not trust our own ideas to the exclusion of wise counselors and what the
Bible has

to say. *Let’s make God a vital part of everything *

*we do, then He will guide us, because we will be working to accomplish His
purpose.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’ Verse:*

*We know that we have come to know Him if we keep His commandments…*

*But if anyone obeys His Word, love for God is truly made complete to t
him. *(I Jn. 2:3, 5)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The question that has been asked more than once is; “How can we know for
sure that we belong to Christ?” This passage gives two ways to know; if
you *do* what Christ says, and *live *as Christ wants. What does Christ
tell us to do? John answers in (3:23) “Believe in the name of His Son,
Jesus Christ *and* love one another.” True Christian faith results in a
loving behavior; that is why John says that, *the way we act can give us
the assurance that we belong to Christ. *

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*And Jesus said to him, “Today salvation has come *

*to this house, **since he also is a son of Abraham. *

*For the Son of Man came to **seek and to save the *

*lost.” *(Lk. 19:9-10)

*Today’s Reflection:*

I am so grateful that Jesus cared about me enough to save me. He willingly
gave His life for mine. And it

does not matter what anyone else thinks. Sometimes

I get so discouraged about things in my life or choices I’ve made that I
don’t feel worthy of anything. But

then I remember that Paul said in Phil. 1:6 that I should be confident in
the knowledge that Jesus will complete the work that He has started in me.

*We all face moments when we feel unworthy. *

*Today, meditate on Phil. 1:6 and remember *

*that Jesus isn’t finished with you! You are *

*worthy in His eyes.*

* Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse:*

*And a voice from heaven said, “This is My son, *

*whom I love; **with Him I am well pleased.” *

(Mt. 3:17)

*Today’s Reflection:*

The heavens opened as the Holy Spirit of God

descended like a dove upon Jesus. Then God spoke

of our Lord, claiming Him and encouraging Him

with words of love. I can’t imagine a more

beautiful scene of power and hope. But in the

very next verse, Jesus was led by the Spirit into

the desert to be tempted by the devil. It’s as if a

giant pendulum swung from the best time possible

to a great trial.Looking back on times you’ve found

yourself head-to-head with temptation, how did

God prepare you before those challenges? Rest

easy, knowing that as He did for Jesus, Our Father

will lead you through.

*Pastor Al*

*Verse:*

Paul says, *put to death your members which are *

*on the **earth: fornication, uncleanness, passion, *

*evil desire, and **covetousness, which is idolatry. *

(Col. 3:5)



*Today’s Reflection:*

As believers we should consider ourselves dead

and unresponsive to sexual immorality, impurity,

lust, shameful desires, and greed. We must make

a conscious daily decision to remove anything that supports or feeds these
desires and to rely on the

Holy Spirit’s power.

*Let us pray for the Holy Spirit’s power to help *

*us **discard our sinful attitudes and behaviors.*

* Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse:*

*He who finds his life will lose it, and he who *

*loses his **life for my sake will find it. *(Mt. 10:39)



*Today’s Reflection:*

This verse is a positive and negative statement

of the same truth. Clinging to this life may cause

us to forfeit the best from Christ in this world

and in the next. The more we love this world’s rewards such as (leisure,
power, popularity,

financial security), the more we will discover

how empty they really are. The best way to enjoy life, therefore, is to loosen
our greedy grasp on earthly rewards so that we can be free to follow
Christ. *In doing so we will inherit **eternal life *

*and begin at once to experience the benefits*

*of following Christ.*

* Pastor Al.*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Jesus turned and saw her. “Take heart, daughter.” *

*He said,**“your faith has healed you,* and the woman

was healed at that moment. (Mt. 9:22)

help us as much as the promise of heaven and the hope we receive through

disappoint you.

*Today's Verse:*
*For in Him we live and move and exist * [*that is, in Him we*
*actually have our being*]. (Acts 17:28)

*Today's Reflection: *
Not only does He give us life, but according to (Gal. 2:20)
Jesus lives in us. The way to live while still here on earth
is by trusting, moment by moment, the Son of God who
loves us and gave Himself for us. So as long as Jesus
allows our heart to keep beating, we need to allow His
love to fill us to the brim, so we can love Him back and
extend that love to others. *Thank God that you are alive!*
*And remember that "In Him we live and move."*
* Pastor Al*

*TODAY'S VERSE:*
Jesus said to Peter and Andrew, "Follow me and I will
make you fishers of man." (Mt. 4:19)

*Today's Reflection:*
Following in the footsteps of Jesus doesn't involve a
check list. True discipleship requires interacting with
Him constantly: remembering His teaching, listening
for His direction, opening our eyes to where He is at
work in our home and community.
*Remember, as Jesus meets us where we are, He*
*shows us new ways to apply those truths as we*
*follow Him.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another. *(Eph. 4:32)



*Today’s Reflection:*

What we should notice by this verse is that we should regard others more
important than ourselves. It seems public unkindness has become an
unpleasant and destructive trend, even with those who should be a

living example to our *nation.* Jesus is alive, and so is

His kindness, and it should live through each believer*.* *Show **someone
today that it is not hard to be a*

*better person.*

* Pastor Al *

Jesus is alive, and so is His kindness, and it should live through each believer. Show someone today that it is not hard to be a better person.
subject: How to be a Better Person
verse_text: Be kind to one another, tenderhearted, forgiving one another.

*Today’s Verse:*

*You are of your father the devil, and the desires of your father y**ou
want to do. He was a murder from the beginning, and does **not stand in the
truth, because there is no truth in him. When **he speaks a lie, he speaks
from his own resources, for he is a **liar and the father of it. *(Jn. 8:44)




*Today’s Reflection:*

Whatever pops up, whether “good” of “bad,” we need

to pause, praise, and pray. We need to attend to whatever it is
without projecting
or jumping to conclusions, knowing Jesus goes with us wherever we go. I
admit it sometimes feels risky to not immediately brace for the worst, *but*
the peace I’ve gained through this practice

is priceless. *Whatever you face today, **bring it to *

*Jesus, giving thanks for the Holy Spirit's power to*

*never let you give up*

*Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse:*

*So I say to you, “Ask and it will be given to you; seek and you will **find;
knock and the door will be opened *

*to you *(Lk. 11:9)


*Today’s Reflection:*

My heart hurts whenever I picture those closed doors.

I think of Jesus letting us know that if we knock, He

will always open the door to us. I guess I’ve always imagined us knocking
to get in and Jesus opening the door to welcome us *inside.* But as I pray for
others, I now realize that sometimes when I knock, we’re the

ones who are inside, and we need Jesus to free us to come out and to let
others pour in. *Following Jesus *

*can mean opening **doors—literal and metaphorical—that create
isolation **between
ourselves and others.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Fear not, for I have redeemed you; I have called you *

*by **your name. *(Isa. 43:1) *(NKJV)*



*Today’s Reflection:*

We are told that we need not fear, but still for some it still is a
constant companion. But if we are walking

with Jesus He has given us a new foundation on which

to stand. Paul says in 2 Cor. 5:17 (NIV) that if we are

in Christ, we are a “new creation.” Jesus gave us the power to step on “all
the power of the enemy without being hurt (Lk. 10:19), KJV, but the bigger
victory is

that our name is written in heaven. *So let us take heart that Jesus knows
our name and we **are His new creation. **He will help us overcome our
fears.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*As Jesus was going down the road, He saw Matthew sitting **at his tax
collector booth. “Follow Me and be *

*My disciple,”**Jesus said to him. So, Matthew got up and followed Him. *(Mt.
9:9) *(NLT)*



*Today’s Reflection:*

Following religious rules doesn’t make us mature believers. It makes us
fearful of the consequences

for breaking them and judgmental toward those who

do not adhere to them. In contrast, following Jesus

places the emphases on a relationship with Him.

When that friendship becomes our focus, everything

else falls into place. *Here is the irony: being Jesus disciple **means we
follow rules designed to make *

*us better Christians.*

* Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse: *

*And we know that God causes everything to work together for **the good of
those who love God and*

* are called according to **His purpose for them. *

(Ro. 8:28)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The statement, *“For our good*,” does not mean that

all that happens to us is good. Evil is prevalent in

our fallen world, but God is able to turn every circumstance around for
our long-range good. Note

that God is not working to make us happy but to

fulfill His purpose. Note also this promise is not for

everybody. It can be claimed only by those who love

God and are called by Him, that is *those* whom the

Holy Spirit convinces to follow Christ. Such people

have a new perspective, a new mind set. They trust

in God, not in worldly treasures: their security is in heaven, not on
earth. Their faith in God does not

waver in pain or persecution because they know

God is with them, and are called according to God’s purpose.

*Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*When the priests withdrew from the Holy Place, the cloud **filled the
temple of the Lord. And the priests*

*could not perform their service because of the cloud. *

*For the glory of the Lord **filled His temple.*

(1 Kings 8:10-11)

*Today’s Reflection:*

Like the priests of old, He’s called each of us to serve

in some way. But let us focus beyond those tangible tasks. Let’s leave room
for Jesus to interrupt and stop

us in our tracks. The glorious presence of the Lord is waiting to fill the
temple of our hearts. *Let’s pause *

*and ask Jesus to make us more **aware of His *

*presence.*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*A leper came to Him begging Him, and kneeling *

*he said to **Him, “If You choose, You can make me *

*clean.” Moved **with pity, Jesus stretched out His *

*hand and touched him, **and said to him, “I do *

*choose, be made whole.” *(Mk. 1:40-41)


*Today’s Reflection:*

As we follow Jesus through the Gospels, one thing

that we will notice is how Jesus spent His time. His calendar gives us a
clear picture of who He really

was. He was visited by shepherds. A man who eat locusts prepared the way
for His ministry, and His

best friends were smelly fishermen. For a greater

list read (Mt. 4:14). Now if Jesus is the embodiment

of God’s will on earth, then it’s clear what His will

is for us as His church, His people. *What **does *

*your schedule show your friends about who you*

*are? *

* Pastor Al*

For a greater list read (Matthew 4:14). Now if Jesus is the embodiment of God’s will on earth, then it’s clear what His will is for us as His church, His people. What does your schedule show your friends about who you are?

reflection:
As we follow Jesus through the Gospels, one thing that we will notice is how Jesus spent His time. His calendar gives us a clear picture of who He really was. He was visited by shepherds. A man who eat locusts prepared the way for His ministry, and His best friends were smelly fishermen.
For a greater list read (Matthew 4:14). Now if Jesus is the embodiment of God’s will on earth, then it’s clear what His will is for us as His church, His people. What does your schedule show your friends about who you are?
subject: What Does Your Schedule Say About You?
verse_text: A leper came to Him begging Him, and kneeling he said to Him, "If You choose, You can make me clean." Moved with pity, Jesus stretched out His hand and touched him, and said to him, "I do choose, be made whole."

*Today’s Verse:*

*In the world you will have tribulation; but be *

*of good **cheer, I have overcome the world. *

(Jn. 16:33)



*Today’s Reflection:*

*Do you ever find yourself* uncertain of how to

console someone who is going through a difficult

time? Questions keep swirling through my head

when I am talking to a friend who needs consoling.

I feel compelled to mention a verse or two, because

it is the desire of Jesus to comfort. When Jesus was

surrounded by masses of hurting people, He had

compassion for them. Jesus tells us to “be of good

cheer” even when facing turbulent times. Whether

we are comforting people who share our faith or

others—who are struggling, we should put them,

in remembrance of the sweet, tender words of

Jesus that are able to sustain us when we are hurting.

*Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*He took our sickness and removed our diseases. *

(Mt. 8:17)



*Today’s Reflection:*

There are times when the answers to my prayers don’t

come as quickly as I want them to, but it still surprises

me when I experience instant relief from Jesus. The

N.T. is filled with stories of how Jesus showed compassion to those who
were suffering, and often

they received their healing immediately. Whatever

the circumstances you should remember Jesus cares

for all of us—men, women, young, old, privileged,

and underprivileged. Jesus was crucified on the cross

for the forgiveness of our sins and the healing of our sicknesses and
diseases. In faith we can cry out to Him

and expect His healing touch. The pain may be gone

right away as it has happened to me at various times,

or the healing may come much latter. But one thing is

certain, Jesus is always concerned with our well-being.

*Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*When you pray, do not use vain repetitions as the heathens *do. For They
think that they will be heard

for their many words. (Mt. 6:7)

*Today’s Reflections:*

Repeating the same words over and over like a magic

incantation is no way to ensure that God will hear your

prayer. It’s not wrong to come to God many times with

your requests—Jesus encourages persistent prayer. *But*

He condemns the shallow repetition of words that are

not offered with a sincere heart. We can never pray to

much if our prayers are honest and sincere. *Before you*

*start to pray, make sure you mean what you say. *

* Pastor Al*

*Today (*1-27-2020) *Verse:*

*Let nothing be done through selfish ambition or *

*conceit, but** in lowliness of mind let each esteem *

*others better than himself. * (Phil. 2:3)



*Today’s Reflection:*

*Selfishness can ruin a church, but genuine humility *

*can **build it. Being humble involves having a true perspective **about
ourselves**. *(see Ro. 12:3) *It does *

*not mean that we **should put ourselves down. Before God, we are
sinners, **saved
only by God’s grace, but *

*we are saved and therefore **have great worth in God’s Kingdom. We are to
lay aside **selfishness and treat *

*others with respect and common **courtesy. *

*When we consider the interests of others more*

*important **then ours it** links us with Christ, who*

* was a true example of **humility.*

* Pastor Al *

*Today’s Verse*

*This is the confidence we have in approaching God; *

*that **If we ask anything according to His will, He *

*hears us. *(I Jn. 5:14)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Other places in Scripture, we also see that God

assures us that He will conform us to Christ’s

likeness. And I believe He will. Our cooperation

hastens this lifelong process. I also believe that

as we mature, our prayers more closely align with

Jesus’s heart, and our eyes are more attuned to how

He works. As years go by I’ve become more con-

vinced, though, sometimes through very painful

lessons, that Jesus’s way is always best, so I’m

more submissive to the stream of His will.

*When I pray and receive, I trust He has been *

*listening and answers.*

*Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*“For my thoughts are not your thoughts. Nor *

*are your **ways my ways,” says the Lord. *(Isa 55:8)



*Today’s Reflection:*

The people of Israel were *foolish *to act as if they knew what God was
thinking and planning. His knowledge and wisdom are far greater than any
human’s. We are *foolish* also to think we can fit God into our mold—to make
His plans and purposes conform to ours. Instead, we must strive

to fit into His plans. *The Lord always **extends *

*an **invitation to us for His salvation.*

* Pastor Al*

The Lord always extends an invitation to us for His salvation.

*Today’s Verse:*

*I can do all things through Christ who strengthens *

*me. *(Phil. 4:13)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Sometimes what a verse doesn’t say is just as important as what the verse
says. I was recently reminded that while I can do all things through Jesus,
He never said

I had to do it all. I’m the one who puts the pressure on myself. Sometimes
the thing He wants to give m*e is* strength for speaking that powerful
little word, “No.”

Jesus wants us to get our value from Him. Not from doing all things. But
from resting in His love for us

and letting His strength shine through our weakness.

But how can we do that if we never admit we have a weakness? *What’s t**he
hardest thing you have to do today?*

* Pastor Al*

*Today’s Verse:*

*Many of the disciples said, “This is very hard to understand.*

*How can anyone accept it?” Jesus was aware that His *

*disciples **were complaining, so He said to them, “Does this offend you?”**At
this point many of His disciples turned away and deserted **Him. *(Jn.
6:60—61, 66)



*Today’s Reflection:*

Offending others when standing for the truth is inevitable. We

can’t control how others receive our words, but we can control

the manner in which we present them. Jesus never stooped to

name calling, or verbally tearing apart the character of anyone

who disagreed with Him. Neither should we. *Our **role is to *

*follow His example and trust His Holy Spirit to **change the *

*hearts of those who take offense. *

* Pastor Al*

Our role is to follow His example and trust His Holy Spirit to change the hearts of those who take offense.
